Award.AbstractNarration:
The Smoky Cascade Geometry Conference will be held at the University of Tennessee at Knoxville March 19--21, 2014. The conference will feature ten plenary speakers with plenty of time between talks to encourage discussion and the interchange of ideas. The key areas represented in the conference will be Metric Geometry, Geometric Flows, Ricci Solitons, Minimal Submanifolds, and the Geometry of Partial Differential Equations. The overlap between these areas makes very real the possibility for cross-collaboration among the participants.

The Smoky Cascade Geometry Conference features important areas of geometry and geometric analysis with leading researchers as speakers. The funding helps to involve early-career mathematicians (including graduate students and postdocs). Particular attention is paid to identifying and supporting women and other members of underrepresented groups.

The webpage for the conference can be found at: https://googledrive.com/host/0B_keKNxvwJfwRV9MdTdlTl9fT0U/Smoky%20Cascades%20Geometry%20Conference.htm

POR.DRECONTENT:
We feel the Smoky Cascade Geometry Conference was a success. There were  a total of 10 plenary talks given over 3 days of the conference, followed by an AMS special session in Metric Geometry, in which 15 shorter talks were given.
9 of the plenary talks were research talks, and one was a survey talk. In general, the research talks were excellent. The committee organized (as much as possible) talks in terms of unifying ideas. Speakers were able to incorporate information from previous talks or signal results that would betalked about that same day thus helping people to see common themes. Since the talks were in different areas of Metric Geometry, the speakers made an extra effort to make their talks accessible to a general audience of geometers.

The total number of participants, including organizers and speakers was 39. There were 3 organizers, 10 Plenary speakers, and 15 speakers at the AMS special session. In the special session, 5 of the speakers were graduate students and 5 were post-docs.Three of the participants who spoke at the AMS special session received travel funding from the AMS to participate in both events.

One of the goals of the workshop was to encourage and foster interactions among the geometry groups of institutions in the Southeast and the Pacific Northwest. Although the meeting served the mathematics community nationwide, we made a special effort to attract graduate students and researchers from the Southeast and the Pacific Northwest. This was in recognition of the fact that several of these institutions are located far from major mathematical centers, and meetings of this nature are not frequent in either region.

 
We were very pleased to have a large number of women participating on all levels as well as post-docs and graduate students. 15 of the 39 participants were women and 20 of the 39 were post-docs or graduate students.

Another important goal of the conference was to raise the visibility of female geometers. We had a 60% representation of women among our plenary speakers this year and a 33% representation of women among the speakers at the AMS special session in Metric Geometry. A large number of participants were very pleased to see so many women present at the conference and communicated this directly to the organizers. Showing female students by sheer presence that there are women working in this area is a subtle, but effective means of encouraging them to study geometry. From this point of view, we feel that the conference was a tremendous success.

We received a large number of unsolicited, extremely favorable comments from students, post-docs and professors and many of the younger participants asked when the next version of the workshop would be held. We have already organized anotherworkshop in 2015 with funding from the NSF which took place at Wichita State University in March, 2015. We  plan to organize another such workshop in 2016 or 2017 and would like to make it an annual event from then on. We hope that the NSF will consider funding the next such workshop, as well as allowing us to turn this an annual event, so that we can achieve an equivalent level of success.
